message_1:
A pharmaceutical company wants to test the effectiveness of a new medicine. They randomly select 100 patients with a certain disease and administer the medicine to them. After a period of time, 85 patients were cured. From previous studies, the company knows that 60% of patients with this disease typically recover without any medication.

What is the statistical inference about the effectiveness of this new medicine compared to the existing treatment?
message_2:
To determine the statistical inference about the effectiveness of the new medicine compared to the existing treatment, we can perform a hypothesis test. We will use a one-sample proportion test to compare the proportion of patients cured by the new medicine to the proportion of patients who recover without any medication.

Null hypothesis (H0): The new medicine has the same effectiveness as no medication (p = 0.60)
Alternative hypothesis (H1): The new medicine has a higher effectiveness than no medication (p > 0.60)

We have a sample size of 100 patients, and 85 of them were cured using the new medicine. Therefore, the sample proportion (p_hat) is 85/100 = 0.85.

Now, we need to calculate the test statistic (z) and the p-value to determine if we can reject the null hypothesis.

The test statistic formula for a one-sample proportion test is:

z = (p_hat - p) / sqrt((p * (1 - p)) / n)

where p is the proportion of patients who recover without any medication (0.60), p_hat is the sample proportion (0.85), and n is the sample size (100).

z = (0.85 - 0.60) / sqrt((0.60 * (1 - 0.60)) / 100)
z = 0.25 / sqrt(0.24 / 100)
z = 0.25 / 0.049

Now, we need to find the p-value associated with this z-score. Since we are testing for a higher effectiveness (one-tailed test), we will look up the area to the right of the z-score in a standard normal distribution table or use a calculator.

The p-value for a z-score of 5.10 is very close to 0 (less than 0.0001).

Since the p-value is very small (less than a typical significance level of 0.05), we reject the null hypothesis. This means that there is strong evidence to suggest that the new medicine has a higher effectiveness than no medication in treating the disease.
